Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 (apportionment of liability / comparative negligence);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 4.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 60 (interest on court judgments) and Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, § 4 (tolling and related provisions), as applicable to remedies and remedies procedure.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: - Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (foreseeability and proximate cause principles);
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The opinion is a leading authority on foreseeability as a limit on duty and thus on proximate cause in negligence. Cardozo holds that negligence is relational and that a defendant owes a duty only to those within the reasonably foreseeable zone of danger; harms to unforeseeable plaintiffs fall outside the scope of liability. This is precisely what is typically meant when Palsgraf is cited for ‘foreseeability and proximate cause principles.’
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… Here, by concession, there was nothing in the situation to suggest to the most cautious mind that the parcel wrapped in newspaper would spread wreckage through the station.”

Degnan v. Tunis, 422 Mass. 629 (1996).proposition: - Degnan v. Tunis, 422 Mass. 629 (1996) (duty and foreseeability principles — Massachusetts SJC precedent on negligence causation);
Degnan v. Tunis, 422 Mass. 629 (1996).support_reasoning: Degnan v. Tunis concerns procedural rights to a hearing on posttrial motions (judgment notwithstanding the verdict and new trial) and the interplay between Superior Court Rules 9A and 26. It does not analyze or set out principles of duty, foreseeability, or negligence causation. Using this case as Massachusetts SJC precedent on negligence duty/foreseeability is inaccurate; its holding is confined to motion practice and hearing requirements.
Degnan v. Tunis, 422 Mass. 629 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "We transferred this case to this court on our own motion to decide whether the defendant, Melvin E. Averett, was entitled to a hearing on his posttrial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict... and for a new trial.... We conclude that the defendant was entitled to a hearing on his posttrial motions. Accordingly, we vacate the orders denying the motions and remand the matter for further proceedings in the Superior Court."

Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 3.raw_text: Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 389 Mass. 404 (1983)
Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 3.proposition: - Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 389 Mass. 404 (1983) (duty and governmental liability principles);
Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 3.case_name: Hearn v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 3.support_reasoning: The case primarily concerns the constitutionality and continued validity of a special two‑year statute of limitations for tort actions against the MBTA, not general ‘duty and governmental liability principles.’ While § 21 (quoted in a footnote) describes MBTA tort liability “to the same extent as though the authority were a street railway company,” the opinion does not analyze or develop substantive duty standards or broader governmental liability doctrines; it focuses on equal protection and implied repeal. Thus it is not a good authority for generic duty/governmental liability principles, though it does confirm the existence of a special statutory liability and limitation period for the MBTA.
Campbell v. Treasurer & Receiver Gen., 3.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 161A, § 21, inserted by St. 1964, c. 563, § 18, states in part: ‘The authority shall be liable for the acts and negligence of the directors and of the servants and employees of the authority in management and operation of the authority and of the properties owned, leased and operated by it to the same extent as though the authority were a street railway company… provided that any action for such personal injury or property damage shall be commenced only within two years next after the date of such injury or damage….’”

Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass.raw_text: Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass. App. Ct. 757 (1997)
Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass.proposition: - Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass. App. Ct. 757 (1997) (apportionment and contributory/comparative fault principles);
Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass.case_name: Tuite & Sons, Inc. v. Shawmut Bank, N.A.
Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion in this excerpt concerns claim preclusion (res judicata) flowing from a prior dismissal with prejudice and related procedural issues. It does not address apportionment of liability, contributory negligence, or comparative fault principles in any way. Therefore, citing this case for apportionment and contributory/comparative fault principles is inaccurate and unsupported by the text provided.
Benoit v. General Insurance Co., 43 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The doctrine of claim preclusion ‘prohibits the maintenance of an action based on the same claim[s] that [were] the subject of an earlier action between the same parties or their privies.’ Bagley v. Moxley, 407 Mass. 633, 636 (1990)."

Hurley v. Milford, 345 Mass. 1 (1962).proposition: - Hurley v. Milford, 345 Mass. 1 (1962) (premises liability and duty to maintain safe conditions);
Hurley v. Milford, 345 Mass. 1 (1962).case_name: Stone & Webster Engineering Corp. v. First National Bank & Trust Co.
Hurley v. Milford, 345 Mass. 1 (1962).support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial paper / bank collection case dealing with forged endorsements, the Uniform Commercial Code, and the rights and liabilities among drawer, drawee bank, and collecting bank. It does not involve premises liability, physical property conditions, or a landowner’s duty to maintain safe conditions for entrants. Citing Hurley v. Milford for a premises-liability duty rule is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
Hurley v. Milford, 345 Mass. 1 (1962).relevant_excerpt: “The questions argued concern the rights of the drawer against a collecting bank which ‘cashed’ checks for an individual who had forged the payee’s indorsement on the checks, which were never delivered to the payee.”

Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350.raw_text: Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350 (1998)
Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350.proposition: - Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350 (1998) (foreseeability and proximate cause);
Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal procedure issues (jury questions handled ex parte, sufficiency of evidence on a firearm charge, and limits on cross-examination). It does not discuss civil or criminal concepts of foreseeability or proximate cause at all. Therefore, citing Breault v. Netwit for a proposition about foreseeability and proximate cause is inaccurate and unsupported by the text of this decision.
Breault v. Netwit, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 350.relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of foreseeability or proximate cause. The court focuses on: (1) the judge’s error in responding to a jury question without notifying counsel; (2) the sufficiency of evidence regarding the barrel length element of an illegal firearm possession charge; and (3) the scope of cross-examination and alleged judicial bias. None of these sections address foreseeability or proximate cause.

Moynihan v. Balboni, 397 Mass. 565 (1986.proposition: - Moynihan v. Balboni, 397 Mass. 565 (1986) (duty of care for property owners);
Moynihan v. Balboni, 397 Mass. 565 (1986.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide case focused on admissibility of forensic bite-mark evidence, joint venture liability, felony murder based on rape, prosecutorial argument, and review under Mass. G.L. c. 278, § 33E. It does not discuss premises liability, negligence standards, or any duty of care owed by property owners. Therefore it does not support a proposition about the duty of care for property owners and appears to be mis-cited for that purpose.
Moynihan v. Balboni, 397 Mass. 565 (1986.relevant_excerpt: The issues presented on appeal are: “(1) Did the judge commit reversible error in admitting expert testimony on bite mark identification evidence? (2) Did the judge commit reversible error in denying a motion for a mistrial when a witness stated that the defendant’s brother had confessed to the crime, and where the evidence indicated association between the brothers? (3) Was it error to instruct the jury on the theory of joint venture? (4) Was it error to instruct the jury on felony-murder, which was based on the felony of rape…?” (No discussion of property owners’ duty of care appears.)

Bessette v. Boston, 372 Mass. 582 (1977).proposition: - Bessette v. Boston, 372 Mass. 582 (1977) (municipal and property-owner obligations with respect to hazards);
Bessette v. Boston, 372 Mass. 582 (1977).case_name: Callahan v. Westinghouse Broadcasting Co., Inc.
Bessette v. Boston, 372 Mass. 582 (1977).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Bessette v. Boston concerns the constitutional standard of proof (“clear and convincing evidence”) for actual malice in defamation actions involving public figures. It does not address municipal or property-owner obligations regarding physical hazards or premises liability. Accordingly, this case does not support the proposition about municipal and property-owner obligations with respect to hazards.
Bessette v. Boston, 372 Mass. 582 (1977).relevant_excerpt: In affirming the judgments in this case the court reaffirms and applies the holding in Stone v. Essex County Newspapers, Inc., 367 Mass. 849, 851, 870 (1975), to the effect that “a plaintiff who is a public officer or a public figure may in such an action recover only on proof of ‘actual malice’ (wilful or reckless disregard of the truth in the publishing of the libel),” and that “as, matter of constitutional law,” a “plaintiff is required to prove actual malice... not merely by the fair preponderance of the evidence, but by ‘clear and convincing proof.’”

Shulman v. Freeman, 385 Mass. 557 (1982).proposition: - Shulman v. Freeman, 385 Mass. 557 (1982) (negligence and causation analysis);
Shulman v. Freeman, 385 Mass. 557 (1982).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a dissent focusing on substituted judgment and the ethics of sterilizing an incompetent person; it does not address negligence or causation doctrine at all. Shulman v. Freeman is a guardianship/sterilization decision, not a tort negligence case, so citing it as authority for “negligence and causation analysis” is inaccurate. Nothing in the quoted reasoning analyzes duty, breach, causation, or damages in the negligence sense.
Shulman v. Freeman, 385 Mass. 557 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The court today has decided that the probate judge has the power to divine the wishes of a severely mentally retarded women… as to whether she should permit herself to be rendered forever incapable of conceiving and bearing a child.… The very condition of incompetence makes the doctrine of substituted judgment a cruel charade.”

Hines v. Aronson, 361 Mass. 429 (1972).proposition: - Hines v. Aronson, 361 Mass. 429 (1972) (duty and breach in premises-liaiblity contexts).
Hines v. Aronson, 361 Mass. 429 (1972).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns interpretation of a deed, whether a railroad has "abandoned passenger service" for purposes of terminating deed covenants, and whether a viaduct was included in the conveyance, not premises-liability, negligence, or duty/breach standards. It does not analyze a landowner’s duty of care to entrants or any breach of that duty, so it cannot serve as authority for duty and breach in premises-liability contexts.
Hines v. Aronson, 361 Mass. 429 (1972).relevant_excerpt: "1. Upon these facts we conclude that the Railroad has not abandoned passenger service within the meaning of the deed covenants. ... 2. The plaintiff’s claim for reimbursement for taxes paid by him is based on his contention that the viaduct was not conveyed to his predecessor in title by the Railroad’s deed of January 12, 1959. ... The conveyance of the land carried with it all permanent buildings and structures thereon, including the viaduct, whether specifically mentioned in the deed or not."
